While the [[Lumberjack|axemen]] were cutting the trees, martyr [[Amrita Devi]] hugged one of the trees. This is because in Jodhpur, each child had a tree that could talk to it. The axmen ignored Devi, and after taking her off the tree, cut it down. Her daughters are environmentalists like [[Chandi Prasad Bhatt]] and Sunderlal Bahuguna.
===Green Belt movement=== Another movement, which is one of the biggest in women and environmental history, is the [http://www.greenbeltmovement.org/ Green Belt movement]. [[Nobel Prize]] winner [[Wangari Maathai]] founded this movement on the [[World Environment Day]] in June 1977. The starting ceremony was very simple: a few women planted seven trees in Maathai's backyard. By 2005, 30 million trees had been planted by participants in the Green Belt movement on public and private lands. The Green Belt movement aims to bring environmental restoration along with society's economic growth. This movement led by Maathai focused on restoration of [[Kenya]]'s rapidly diminishing forests as well as empowering the rural women through environmental preservation, with a special emphasis on planting indigenous trees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Green Belt Movement|date=2006|access-date=November 15, 2006|url= http://www.wangarimaathai.or.ke/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Muthuki|first=Janet|date=2006-01-01|title=Challenging patriarchal structures: Wangari Maathai and the Green Belt Movement in Kenya|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233277225|journal=Agenda|volume=20|issue=69 |pages=83–91|doi=10.1080/10130950.2006.9674752|s2cid=142391945 }}</ref>
===Navdanya Movement=== [[Navdanya]] also known as the 'Nine Seeds Movement' seeks to empower local Indian farmers to move away from growing any [[genetically modified organism]] (GMOs) on their land and return to organic, [[chemical-free]] practices. This movement has reached over 5,000,000 Indian farmers and created over 65 seed banks around India.<ref name="home">{{cite web|title=Navdanya|access-date=March 5, 2012|url= http://www.navdanya.org/home}}</ref> Navdanya fights to eliminate the [[commercialization of indigenous knowledge]] also known as 'Biopiracy'.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Yamey, Gavin|title=The Bittersweet Sounds of the Modern Food Chain|journal=PLOS Biology|date=February 2006|volume=4|issue=2|pages=0165–0166|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.0040047|pmc=1363707}}</ref> Navdanya addresses multiple other international issues including climate change, food security, misapplication of technology, [[food sovereignty]], fair trade, and many others.<ref name="home"/> This movement also created a learning center entitled Bija Vidyapeeth. Bija Vidyapeeth, in collaboration with Schumacher College in the United Kingdom, seeks to educate participants in sustainability and ecological principles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Navdanya|access-date=March 2, 2012|url= http://www.navdanya.org/earth-university}}</ref>
===Kenyan land takeover=== In Kenya, starting in the mid-1980s, women protested against the elites and big foreign corporations who were coercing and controlling the production of the land. Rather than allowing food to be grown for survival, women were pressured by both their husbands and the government to cultivate coffee for foreign profit. Protests continued and gained strength over the next couple of decades. The protests eventually ended in a Kenyan power shift enforcing democratic national elections which resulted in redistribution of land possible.<ref name=Perkins>{{cite journal|author1=Perkins, E.|author2=Kuiper, E.|author3=Quiroga-Martínez, R.|author4=Turner, T. E.|author5=Brownhill, L.S.|author6=Mellor, M.|author7=Todorova, Z.|author8=Jochimsen, M.A.|author9=McMahon, M.|year=2005|title=Explorations: feminist ecological economics|journal=Feminist Economics|volume=11|issue=3|pages=107–150|doi=10.1080/13545700500301494|s2cid=143586049|url=https://yorkspace.library.yorku.ca/xmlui/handle/10315/37139}}</ref>
=== Dakota Access Pipeline protests === The [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests]] (also known by the hashtag campaign [[NODAPL|#NoDAPL]]) was an opposition to the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline. The [[Dakota Access Pipeline]] is 1,172 miles long, traveling from North to South Dakota and has the capability of transporting thousands of barrels of oil.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Whyte|first=Kyle|date=2017-01-01|title=The Dakota Access Pipeline, Environmental Injustice, and U.S. Colonialism|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/312040136|journal=Red Ink |volume=19|issue=1|pages=154–169}}</ref> The pipeline runs under [[Lake Oahe]], an important water source for the [[Standing Rock Indian Reservation|Standing Rock Reservation]] located near the projected site in South Dakota.<ref name=":12" /> In 2016 construction was set to begin but was soon halted by the opposition the project faced.<ref name=":12" /> The [[Standing Rock Indian Reservation|Standing Rock Reservation]] claimed that the construction of the pipeline was an environmental injustice and could lead to their water source becoming polluted if the pipeline was to burst.<ref name=":12" /> The reservation also claimed that the proposed site that was to be dug was sacred ground and contained buried ancestors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morris|first=Catherine|date=2016|title=Tribal Culture, Oil Access Collide in North Dakota|url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/6801d48a34cff799d8958d25365887aa/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=27805|journal=Diverse Issues in Higher Education|volume=33}}</ref> The [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]], who were responsible for approving the permit needed to proceed with construction, claimed that proper assessments had been taken to ensure that it was environmentally and culturally safe to proceed with the completion of the pipeline.<ref name=":12" /> With the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] continuing to move forward with construction the [[NoDAPL]] movement was created in April 2016 to try to halt construction of the pipeline in order to protect the Standing Rock Reservation's water source and members.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Steinman|first=Erich|title=Why was Standing Rock and the #NoDAPL campaign so historic? Factors affecting American Indian participation in social movement collaborations and coalitions|journal=Ethnic and Racial Studies|volume=42|issue=7|pages=1070–1090|doi=10.1080/01419870.2018.1471215|year=2019|s2cid=149696286}}</ref> The movement grew historically large due to the threat of pollution and violence against women.<ref name=":13" />
Although the [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|NoDAPL]] movement was largely labeled as only an environmental justice movement, the NoDAPL movement's concerns were also gendered. The gendered perspective of the NoDAPL movement was told in the documentary, ''Rise: Standing Rock'' <ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://transcripts.foreverdreaming.org/viewtopic.php?f=820&t=30811|title=Transcript for Rise: Standing Rock Documentary 1x01|last=VICE|first=LAND|date=2017}}</ref>''.'' Many Standing Rock tribe members claimed that the construction of the pipeline would also lead to an increase of sexual violence against women and girls living on the reservation.<ref name=":14" /> Visiting tribe members from the [[Fort Berthold Indian Reservation|Fort Berthold Reservation]] shared stories of the danger young girls now faced after the increase of [[Hydraulic fracturing|fracking]] in their community.<ref name=":14" /> A [[Fort Berthold Indian Reservation|Fort Berthold]] tribe member described how oil workers would pick up young girls walking home within the reservation and kidnap them to be sold amongst the workers for sex.<ref name=":14" /> According to the book, ''The Beginning and End of Rape: Confronting Sexual Violence in Native America'', Indigenous women are more likely to experience sexual violence than any other ethnic groups.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Beginning and End of Rape: Confronting Sexual Violence in Native America|last=Deer|first=Sarah|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|year=2015}}</ref> Although there are many factors that contribute to those high numbers in a 2013 article, Genevieve Le May stated that the increase of oil extraction sites and pipelines near reservations is a big contributing factor due to “man camps” built by reservations to house the oil workers.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Le May|first=Genevieve|date=2018|title=The Cycles of Violence Against Native Women: An Analysis of Colonialism, Historical Legislation and the Violence Against Women Reauthorization Act of 2013|url=https://pdxscholar.library.pdx.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1177&context=mcnair|journal=PSU McNair Scholars Online Journal|volume=12|doi=10.15760/mcnair.2018.1}}</ref> Le May also claims that it is hard for reservations to seek justice for sexual assaults due to lack of police interference.<ref name=":15" /> That is why the mobilization of Indigenous people, particularly Indigenous women, in the [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|NoDAPL]] movement was considered to be historical to some.<ref name=":13" /> The documentary also stated that the water from [[Lake Oahe]] was heavily used by women living on the reservation and was another factor for women involvement.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://transcripts.foreverdreaming.org/viewtopic.php?f=820&t=30909|title=Transcript for Rise Standing Rock Documentary 1x02|last=VICE|first=LAND|date=2017}}</ref> Many female tribe members explained that the water coming out of their faucets was water from the lake. This means that any pollution to the lake would directly affect them and their families since they drink, bathe and cook with the water.<ref name=":16" />
Because this pipeline directly affected their community, participants of the [[NoDAPL]] movement originated with the Sioux Tribe of [[Standing Rock Indian Reservation|Standing Rock]].<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Cronin|first=Janelle|date=2018|title=Living in a Liminal Space Standing Rock and Storytelling as a Tool of Activism|url=https://www.proquest.com/openview/9b53309524ab0098e24b7871b93be30b/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750&diss=y|journal=ProQuest Dissertations}}</ref> The movement grew due to support of tribes across the nation, including many members that travelled to [[Standing Rock Indian Reservation|Standing Rock Reservation]].<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Ferguson|first=Mary|date=2018|title=Native Youth Contributions to Indigenous Sovereignty and Climate Justice in the noDAPL Movement|url=https://scarab.bates.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1279&context=honorstheses|journal=Bates College: Honors Theses|volume=256}}</ref> Due to social media the NoDAPL movement was able to include thousands of supporters from all over the world.<ref name=":18" /> The [[NoDAPL]] movement included many protests at Standing Rock Reservation and confrontations with police and NoDAPL supporters all throughout 2016.<ref name=":16" /> During his last few months in office [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] responded to the protests by ceasing all construction of the pipeline.<ref name=":13" /> The halt of construction was short due to succeeding president, [[Donald Trump]].<ref name=":13" /> During the first year of his administration, [[Donald Trump|President Donald Trump]] ordered for the completion of the [[Dakota Access Pipeline]] which occurred in 2017.<ref name=":13" />
In the article “Living In A Liminal Space: Standing Rock And Storytelling As A Tool Of Activism”, author Janelle Cronin states that one of the NoDAPL women leaders that needs recognition is [[LaDonna Brave Bull Allard|LaDonna BraveBull Allard]], a member of the Sioux Tribe of Standing Rock.<ref name=":17" /> In 2016 Allard published a video on Facebook asking for the surrounding tribes to come and support Standing Rock in protesting the pipeline, sparking public interest in the [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|NoDAPL]] movement.<ref name=":17" /> In response to people answering her call, Allard created Sacred Stone Camp, which housed protestors for the months that the NoDAPL movement took place.<ref name=":18" /> The [[Viceland|VICELAND]] documentary Rise: Standing Rock showed that Allard provided the camp with food and anything else needed to keep the camp functioning, paying with donations given as well as out of her own pocket.<ref name=":14" /> Even though the pipeline has been completed, the Sacred Stone Camp remains. The camp's official website claims that there is still a need to educate people about the importance of a sustainable lifestyle as well as a need to protect water due to threats that still exist globally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sacredstonevillage.net/|title=Sacred Stone Village|last=Sacred|first=Stone Village|date=2018-12-12|website=Sacred Stone Village}}</ref> Another noticeable leader in the NoDAPL movement is Bobbi Jean Three Legs, another member of the Sioux Tribe. In her article, Mary Ferguson claims that Bobbi played an important role in keeping the nation's attention on Standing Rock.<ref name=":18" /> Bobbie and other young tribe members organized a run that would take them from South Dakota to Washington, D.C.<ref name=":18" /> This run was created in order to hand deliver a petition asking the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] to deny the construction of the pipeline through their water source.<ref name=":18" /> Bobbi claimed that she became involved with [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|NoDAPL]] because of her concern for future generations living on the reservation and because she wanted to make sure that clean water would always be available for her daughter.<ref name=":14" />
